# B Additional Lemmas 

Lemma B.1. (e.g., Theorem 3.1 of Pinkus (1999)) Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $K \subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ be a compact subset. For any $\varepsilon>0$ and continuous function $f(x), x \in K$, there exists an ANN, denoted by $\hat{f}$, such that $\sup _{x \in K}\|f(x)-\hat{f}(x)\|<\varepsilon$ if and only if the activation function is not a polynomial.

Lemma B.2. (Lemma 6.4 of Coache and Jaimungal (2024)) Let $d \in \mathbb{N}$ and $K \subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ be a compact subset. For any $\varepsilon>0$ and ensemble of a finite number of $A N N s\left\{\hat{f}_{t}(x)\right\}_{t \in \mathcal{T}}, x \in K$, there exists an $A N N$, denoted by $\hat{g}$, such that $\sup _{x \in K}\left\|\hat{f}_{t}(x)-\hat{g}_{t}(x)\right\|<\varepsilon, \forall t \in \mathcal{T}$.

Lemma B.3. Let $\rho_{t}$ be a monetary one-step conditional risk measure - that is cash additive, where $\rho_{t}(m+Z)=$ $m+\rho_{t}(Z)$ for any $m \in \mathcal{Z}_{t}$, and monotone, where $Z \leq W$ implies $\rho_{t}(Z) \leq \rho_{t}(W)$. Consider the robust version $\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}$ under the 2-Wasserstein distance with an uncertainty set of either the form Eq. (2.2a) or Eq. (2.2b). Then, $\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}$ remains monetary.

Proof. We have that $\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}$ is cash additive since, for any $m \in \mathcal{Z}_{t}$,

$$
\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}(m+Z)=\underset{Z^{\phi} \in \varphi_{m+Z}^{\epsilon_{s}}}{\operatorname{ess} \sup } \rho_{t}\left(Z^{\phi}\right)=\underset{Z^{\phi} \in \varphi_{Z}^{\epsilon_{s}}}{\operatorname{ess} \sup } \rho_{t}\left(m+Z^{\phi}\right)=m+\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}(Z)
$$

Next, we show that $\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}$ remains monotone by contradiction using the fact that the conditional 2-Wasserstein distance defines a metric on the space of probability measures. We define $Z^{*}:=\arg \max _{Z^{\phi} \in \varphi_{Z}^{\epsilon_{s}}} \rho_{t}\left(Z^{\phi}\right)$ and denote the conditional quantile functions of $Z, Z^{*}$ and $W$ by respectively $\bar{F}_{t}, \bar{F}_{*, t}$ and $\bar{G}_{t}$. Let $Z \leq W$ and assume that $Z^{*}>W^{*}$. We cannot have $\left\langle\bar{F}_{*, t}, \bar{G}_{t}\right\rangle \leq \epsilon_{s}$, because we would obtain $Z^{*} \leq W^{*}$. On the other hand, if $\left\langle\bar{F}_{*, t}, \bar{G}_{t}\right\rangle>\epsilon_{s}$, we get, using the triangle inequality, that

$$
\epsilon_{s}<\left\langle\bar{F}_{*, t}, \bar{G}_{t}\right\rangle \leq\left\langle\bar{F}_{*, t}, \bar{F}_{t}\right\rangle+\left\langle\bar{F}_{t}, \bar{G}_{t}\right\rangle \leq \epsilon_{s}+\left\langle\bar{F}_{t}, \bar{G}_{t}\right\rangle
$$

which leads to a contradiction, since $\left\langle\bar{F}_{t}, \bar{G}_{t}\right\rangle \geq 0$. Therefore, we must have $Z^{*} \leq W^{*}$ and

$$
\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}(Z)=\rho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}\left(Z^{*}\right) \leq \rho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}\left(W^{*}\right)=\varrho_{t}^{\epsilon_{s}}(W)
$$

where the inequality follows from the monotonicity of $\rho_{t}$.

# C Proofs
## C. 1 Proof of Theorem 3.2

Proof. Since we are working with distortion risk measures and the Wasserstein distance, both components of the optimization problem in Eq. (3.2) can be expressed in terms of quantile functions instead of random variables. Indeed, we have

$$
\varphi_{\bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)}^{\epsilon_{s}}=\left\{\bar{F} \in \overline{\mathbb{F}}:\left\|\bar{F}(\cdot \mid s, a)-\bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)\right\| \leq \epsilon_{s}\right\}
$$

and the one-step conditional distortion risk measure $\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \bar{F}_{\phi, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)\right\rangle$. Therefore, we have the equivalence relationship

$$
\underset{Z_{t}^{\phi} \in \varphi_{Z_{t}^{\phi}}}{\operatorname{ess} \sup } \rho_{t}^{\gamma_{s}}\left(Z_{t}^{\phi} \mid s_{t}=s, a_{t}=a\right) \equiv \underset{\bar{F}_{\phi, t} \in \varphi_{\bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot s, a)}^{\epsilon_{s}}}{\operatorname{ess} \sup }\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \bar{F}_{\phi, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)\right\rangle
$$

where the equivalence is to be understood as: (i) the quantile function of any optimal random variable for the left-hand side of Eq. (C.1) is optimal for the right-hand side; and (ii) any random variable with an optimal quantile function for the right-hand side of Eq. (C.1) is optimal for the left-hand side. Here, we remark that, as opposed to the original formulation of the problem, the optimization problem on the right-hand side is convex over the space of quantile functions. We use the Lagrange multiplier method to find the optimal solution. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi, t}, \lambda ; \theta\right) \\
& =\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \bar{F}_{\phi, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)\right\rangle-\lambda\left(\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)-\bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)\right\|^{2}-\epsilon_{s}^{2}\right) \\
& \text { [square completion] }=-\lambda\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)-\left(\bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)+\frac{\gamma_{s}}{2 \lambda}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& \quad+\lambda\left(\epsilon_{s}^{2}-\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)\right\|^{2}\right)+\frac{\left\|2 \lambda \bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)+\gamma_{s}\right\|^{2}}{4 \lambda} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Slater's condition and the convexity of the quantile representation problem, strong duality holds:

$$
Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)=\max _{\bar{F}_{\phi, t} \in \overline{\mathbb{F}}} \min _{\lambda>0} L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi, t}, \lambda ; \theta\right)=\min _{\lambda>0} \max _{\bar{F}_{\phi, t} \in \overline{\mathbb{F}}} L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi, t}, \lambda ; \theta\right)
$$

Since only the first integral in Eq. (C.2) actually depends on $\bar{F}_{\phi}$, the inner optimization problem is attained for a given $\lambda$ by the isotonic projection

$$
\bar{F}_{\phi, t}^{*}(\cdot \mid s, a)=\left(\bar{F}_{\theta, t}(\cdot \mid s, a)+\frac{\gamma_{s}(\cdot)}{2 \lambda}\right)^{\top}
$$

Finally, for the outer problem, the Wasserstein constraint is binding, and thus the optimal $\lambda^{*}$ is the positive value such that $\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi, t}^{*}-\bar{F}_{\theta, t}\right\|=\epsilon_{s}$, which gives the desired result.

## C. 2 Proof of Theorem 3.5

Proof. Similarly to Theorem 3.2, we use the Lagrange multiplier method to find the optimal solution. This differs from the original proof from Bernard et al. (2023), which uses properties of the covariance. In this proof, we remove the dependence on the time and state-action pair for readability. By square completion, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta ; \theta\right) \\
& \quad=\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \bar{F}_{\phi}\right\rangle-\lambda\left(\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}-\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}-\epsilon_{s}^{2}\right)-\zeta\left(\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}\right\|^{2}-\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}\right)-\eta\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\phi}, 1\right\rangle-\mu\right) \\
& \quad=-(\lambda+\zeta)\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}-\frac{2 \lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}-\eta}{2(\lambda+\zeta)}\right\|^{2}+(\zeta-\lambda)\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}+\lambda \epsilon_{s}^{2}+\eta \mu+\frac{\left\|2 \lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}-\eta\right\|^{2}}{4(\lambda+\zeta)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Slater's condition and the convexity of the quantile representation problem, strong duality holds. The optimal quantile function thus has the following form:

$$
\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}=\frac{2 \lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}-\eta}{2(\lambda+\zeta)}=\frac{\lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}-a_{\lambda}}{b_{\lambda}}
$$

From the Lagrangian constraint on the first moment, we get

$$
\left\langle\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, 1\right\rangle=\mu \Longrightarrow a_{\lambda}=(\lambda \mu+1)-b_{\lambda} \mu
$$

From the Lagrangian constraint on the second moment, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}\right\|^{2}=\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2} & \Longrightarrow b_{\lambda}^{2} \sigma^{2}=\left\|\lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}\right\|^{2}-(\lambda \mu+1)^{2} \\
& \Longrightarrow b_{\lambda}=\frac{\sqrt{(\lambda \sigma)^{2}+\sigma_{\gamma}^{2}+2 \lambda\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)}}{\sigma}
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, let $K=\sigma^{2}-\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{2}$. From the Lagrangian constraint on the Wasserstein distance, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}-\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}=\epsilon^{2} \\
& \Longrightarrow\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}\right\|^{2}+\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}-2\left\langle\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \bar{F}_{\theta}\right\rangle=\epsilon^{2} \\
& \Longrightarrow K=\frac{\lambda\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}+\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-a_{\lambda} \mu}{b_{\lambda}}-\mu^{2} \\
& \Longrightarrow b_{\lambda} K=\lambda \sigma^{2}+\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu \\
& \Longrightarrow K^{2}\left((\lambda \sigma)^{2}+\sigma_{\gamma}^{2}+2 \lambda\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)\right)=\sigma^{2}\left(\lambda \sigma^{2}+\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)^{2} \\
& \Longrightarrow K^{2}\left(\lambda^{2} \sigma^{2}+\sigma_{\gamma}^{2}+2 \lambda\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)\right) \\
& \quad=\sigma^{2}\left(\lambda^{2} \sigma^{4}+\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)^{2}+2 \lambda \sigma^{2}\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)\right) \\
& \Longrightarrow \lambda^{2} \sigma^{2}+2 \lambda\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)+\frac{K^{2} \sigma_{\gamma}^{2}-\sigma^{2}\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)^{2}}{K^{2}-\sigma^{4}}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

The discriminant of Eq. (C.4), a quadratic equation in $\lambda$, is

$$
\Delta=4\left(\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)^{2}+\sigma^{2} \frac{\sigma^{2}\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)^{2}-K^{2} \sigma_{\gamma}^{2}}{K^{2}-\sigma^{4}}\right)
$$

must be nonnegative. Indeed, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have respectively

$$
K^{2}-\sigma^{4}=\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \bar{F}_{\theta}\right\rangle-\mu^{2}\right)^{2}-\sigma^{4} \leq\left(\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}\right\|\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|-\mu^{2}\right)^{2}-\sigma^{4}=0
$$

and

$$
\sigma^{2}\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)^{2}-K^{2} \sigma_{\gamma}^{2} \leq \sigma^{2}\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)^{2}-\sigma^{4} \sigma_{\gamma}^{2} \leq 0
$$

Therefore, the quadratic equation in Eq. (C.4) has two roots, which only one is positive, more precisely

$$
\lambda^{*}=\frac{-2\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\theta}, \gamma_{s}\right\rangle-\mu\right)+\sqrt{\Delta}}{2 \sigma^{2}}
$$

If the uncertainty tolerance $\epsilon_{s}$ is large enough and satisfies Eq. (3.4), then $\mu+\frac{\gamma_{s}(u)-1}{b_{0}}$ solves the optimization problem $Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)$. Indeed, it is admissible and for all $\lambda>0$, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \mu+\frac{\gamma_{s}(u)-1}{b_{0}}\right\rangle & =\mu+\sigma \sigma_{\gamma} \\
& \geq \mu+\sigma \frac{\left\langle\gamma_{s},\left(\lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}\right)-(\lambda \mu+1)\right\rangle}{\sqrt{\left\|\lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}\right\|^{2}-(\lambda \mu+1)^{2}}} \\
& =\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \mu+\frac{\left(\lambda \bar{F}_{\theta}+\gamma_{s}\right)-(\lambda \mu+1)}{b_{\lambda}}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

This concludes the proof.

# C. 3 Proof of Theorem 3.6 

Proof. Using the quantile representation and strong duality from Theorem 3.5, we have

$$
\nabla_{\theta} V_{t}(s ; \theta)=\nabla_{\theta} \min _{\lambda, \zeta, \eta>0} \max _{\bar{F}_{\phi} \in \mathbb{F}} L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta ; \theta\right)
$$

We apply the Envelope theorem for saddle-point problems Milgrom and Segal (2002), which differs from standard results by considering arbitrary choice sets instead of convex ones. All conditions of the theorem hold, because the optimization problem is convex over the space of quantile functions: (i) $L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta ; \theta\right)$ is absolutely continuous in $\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta\right)$, because of the convexity and the fact that a distortion risk measure is monetary, and thus Lipschitz and absolutely continuous; (ii) $\nabla_{\theta} L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta ; \theta\right)$ is continuous and bounded at each $\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta\right)$, since $L$ is Lipschitz; (iii) there exists at least one saddle-point, as shown in Theorem 3.2; and (iv) $\left\{L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta ; \theta\right)\right\}_{\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta\right)}$ is equidifferentiable in $\theta$, i.e. its derivative wrt $\theta$ converges uniformly. This leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla_{\theta} V_{t}(s ; \theta)=\left.\nabla_{\theta} L\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}, \lambda, \zeta, \eta ; \theta\right)\right|_{\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}=\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda=\lambda^{*}, \zeta=\zeta^{*}, \eta=\eta^{*}\right)} \\
& =\nabla_{\theta}\left(\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \bar{F}_{\phi}\right\rangle-\lambda\left(\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}-\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}-\epsilon_{s}^{2}\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad-\zeta\left(\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}\right\|^{2}-\left\|\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}\right)-\eta\left(\left\langle\bar{F}_{\phi}, 1\right\rangle-\mu\right)\right)\left.\right|_{\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first term of Eq. (C.5), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla_{\theta}\left\langle\gamma_{s}, \bar{F}_{\phi}\right\rangle\left\lvert\,_{\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)}\right. \\
& =\nabla_{\theta} \int_{0}^{1} \gamma_{s}(u) \bar{F}_{\phi}\left(\left.u\right| s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} u\left|_{\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)}\right. \\
& =\nabla_{a} \int_{0}^{1} \gamma_{s}(u) \bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}\left(\left.u\right| s_{t}, a\right) \mathrm{d} u\left|{ }_{u=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)=\left.\nabla_{a} Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)\right|_{u=\pi^{\theta}(s)} \nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

For the second term of Eq. (C.5), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\left.\nabla_{\theta} \lambda\left(\left\|\bar{F}_{\phi}-\bar{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}-\epsilon_{s}^{2}\right)\right|_{\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)} \\
& \quad=-\left.\nabla_{\theta} \lambda\left(\int_{0}^{1}\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}\left(\left.u\right| s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)-\bar{F}_{\theta}\left(\left.u\right| s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} u-\epsilon_{s}^{2}\right)\right|_{\left(\bar{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
=-2 \lambda^{*} \int_{0}^{1} & \left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)-\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right) \\
& \times \nabla_{\theta}\left(\check{F}_{\phi}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)-\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid_{\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)} \\
=-2 \lambda^{*} & \left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1}\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)-\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right) \\
& \times \nabla_{a}\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right)-\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right)\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \\
=-2 \lambda^{*} & \left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1}\left(\frac{2 \lambda^{*} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)+\gamma_{s}(u)-\eta^{*}}{2\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)}-\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right) \\
& \times\left(\frac{2 \lambda^{*}}{2\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)}-1\right) \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \\
= & \frac{4 \lambda^{*} \zeta^{*}\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right)}{4\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)^{2}} \int_{0}^{1}\left(\gamma_{s}(u)-\eta^{*}-2 \zeta^{*} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right) \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

For the third term of Eq. (C.5), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\nabla_{\theta} \zeta\left(\left\|\check{F}_{\phi}\right\|^{2}-\left\|\check{F}_{\theta}\right\|^{2}\right) \mid_{\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)} \\
& =-\nabla_{\theta} \zeta \int_{0}^{1}\left(\check{F}_{\phi}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right)^{2}-\left(\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} u \mid_{\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)} \\
& =2 \zeta^{*}\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right) \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \\
& \quad-\frac{4 \lambda^{*} \zeta^{*}\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right)}{4\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)^{2}} \int_{0}^{1}\left(2 \lambda^{*} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)+\gamma_{s}(u)-\eta^{*}\right) \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

For the fourth term of Eq. (C.5), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\nabla_{\theta} \eta\left(\left\langle\check{F}_{\phi}, 1\right\rangle-\mu\right) \mid_{\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)} \\
& =-\nabla_{\theta} \eta \int_{0}^{1} \check{F}_{\phi}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)-\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid_{\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}, \lambda^{*}, \zeta^{*}, \eta^{*}\right)} \\
& =-\eta^{*}\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1} \nabla_{a}\left(\check{F}_{\phi}^{*}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right)-\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right)\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \\
& =-\eta^{*}\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1}\left(\frac{2 \lambda^{*}}{2\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)}-1\right) \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \\
& =\frac{2 \eta^{*} \zeta^{*}}{2\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)}\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1} \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining all terms in Eqs. (C.6) to (C.9) together, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla_{\theta} V_{t}(s ; \theta) \\
& =\left.\nabla_{a} Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}(s)} \nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)+\frac{2 \eta^{*} \zeta^{*}}{2\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)}\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1} \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \\
& \quad+\left.\left(2 \zeta^{*}-\frac{4 \lambda^{*} \zeta^{*}}{2\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)}\right)\left(\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\right) \int_{0}^{1}\left(\check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)\right) \nabla_{a} \check{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, a\right) \mid_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \\
& =\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\left(\nabla_{a} Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}(s)}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
+\frac{2 \zeta^{*}}{2\left(\lambda^{*}+\zeta^{*}\right)} \int_{0}^{1}\left(2 \zeta^{*} \bar{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)+\eta^{*}\right) \nabla_{a} \bar{F}_{\theta}\left(\left.u \mid s_{t}, a\right)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u
$$

Using the notation in Theorem 3.5 with $\lambda, b_{\lambda}, a_{\lambda}$, especially Eq. (C.3), and interpreting the integral as an expectation over a uniform random variable, we get the gradient of the value function and, hence, the Q-function:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla_{\theta} V_{t}(s ; \theta) \\
& =\left.\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\left(\nabla_{a} Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}(s)}\right. \\
& \quad+\frac{b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}}{b_{\lambda^{*}}} \int_{0}^{1}\left(\left.\left(b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}\right)\left(\bar{F}_{\theta}\left(u \mid s_{t}, \pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)\right)-\mu\right)+1\right) \nabla_{a} \bar{F}_{\theta}\left(\left.u \mid s_{t}, a\right)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}\left(s_{t}\right)} \mathrm{d} u\right) \\
& =\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\left(\nabla_{a} Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}(s)} \\
& \quad+\frac{b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}}{b_{\lambda^{*}}} \mathbb{E}_{t, s}\left[\left(\left(b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}\right)\left(Z_{t}^{\theta}-\mu\right)+1\right) \nabla_{a} \bar{F}_{\theta}(x \mid s, a)\right|_{(x, a)=\left(Z_{t}^{\theta}, \pi^{\theta}(s)\right)} \mid\right) \\
& =\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\left(\nabla_{a} Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}(s)} \\
& \quad-\frac{b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}}{b_{\lambda^{*}}} \mathbb{E}_{t, s}\left[\left(\left(b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}\right)\left(Z_{t}^{\theta}-\mu\right)+1\right) \frac{\nabla_{a} F_{\theta}(x \mid s, a)}{f_{\theta}(x \mid s, a)}\right|_{(x, a)=\left(Z_{t}^{\theta}, \pi^{\theta}(s)\right)} \mid\right) \\
& =\nabla_{\theta} \pi^{\theta}(s)\left(\nabla_{a} Q_{t}(s, a ; \theta)\right|_{a=\pi^{\theta}(s)} \\
& \quad-\frac{b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}}{b_{\lambda^{*}}} \mathbb{E}_{t, s}\left[\left(\left(b_{\lambda^{*}}-\lambda^{*}\right)\left(Z_{t}^{\theta}-\mu\right)+1\right) \frac{\nabla_{a} F_{\theta}(x \mid s, a)}{\nabla_{x} F_{\theta}(x \mid s, a)}\right|_{(x, a)=\left(Z_{t}^{\theta}, \pi^{\theta}(s)\right)} \mid\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, we write the gradient of a quantile function by instead considering the gradient of the CDF. Indeed, for any CDF $F_{\theta}$, using the fact that $F_{\theta}\left(\bar{F}_{\theta}(u)\right)=u$ and the chain rule to expand the gradient in terms of the partial derivatives, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \nabla_{\theta} F_{\theta}\left(\bar{F}_{\theta}(u)\right)=\nabla_{\theta} u \\
& \Longleftrightarrow \nabla_{x} F_{\theta}(x)\left.\right|_{x=\bar{F}_{\theta}(u)} \nabla_{\theta} \bar{F}_{\theta}(u)+\left.\nabla_{\theta} F_{\theta}(x)\right|_{x=\bar{F}_{\theta}(u)}=0 \\
& \Longleftrightarrow \nabla_{\theta} \bar{F}_{\theta}(u)=-\left.\frac{\left.\nabla_{\theta} F_{\theta}(x)\right|_{x=\bar{F}_{\theta}(u)}}{f_{\theta}\left(\bar{F}_{\theta}(u)\right)}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

abstract:
In a reinforcement learning (RL) setting, the agent's optimal strategy
heavily depends on her risk preferences and the underlying model dynamics of
the training environment. These two aspects influence the agent's ability to
make well-informed and time-consistent decisions when facing testing
environments. In this work, we devise a framework to solve robust risk-aware RL
problems where we simultaneously account for environmental uncertainty and risk
with a class of dynamic robust distortion risk measures. Robustness is
introduced by considering all models within a Wasserstein ball around a
reference model. We estimate such dynamic robust risk measures using neural
networks by making use of strictly consistent scoring functions, derive policy
gradient formulae using the quantile representation of distortion risk
measures, and construct an actor-critic algorithm to solve this class of robust
risk-aware RL problems. We demonstrate the performance of our algorithm on a
portfolio allocation example.
